Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:To gain her trust the real estate agent was very polite, delightful and all around what? She was polite, charitable, and manipulative.<n><n>#### Answer:B<n><n>### Input;The price of each item in the shop is double their original cost. For example: â€œFor this task, you will need to answer a question that involves a situation in a given context.â€<n><n>The last sentence of the task should conclude with a call to action, for example, â€œAnswer the questions.â€<n><n>### Question Prompts<n><n>After the general instruction statement, include one or more question prompts, which may include a scenario, scenario, and a picture.<n><n>### Context<n>This is the first part of the task where you establish the context for the question prompts.<n><n>### Questions<n>This part of the task will contain one or more questions. The questions could be multiple choice, essay, short answers, or other.<n>### Notes<n>After questions, you may include notes. These are used for additional explanation that apply to all or most of the questions. Alternatively, you may use these to give additional explanation for questions that follow a logical order.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Remembering past successe is likely to cause what? Choices:  A: problems B: crying C: inspiration D: trauma E: nightmares<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>---<n><n>

The input must be on one line, followed by a newline (optional) and followed by an 'end'.  The output must be the mean of the input, and the output must be on a single line, followed by a "\n".<n>### Input Example<n><n>6 15 22 31 41 60 23<n><n>### Output Example:<n><n>19<n><n>### Solution: <n><n>### Java<n><n>import java.util.Scanner;<n>public class Mean {<n>    public static void main(String[] args) {<n>        Scanner in = new Scanner(System.in);<n>        double mean = 0.0;<n><n>        String in1 = in.nextLine(); // The line with the numbers is put here and the next command is below.<n><n>        System.out.print("Enter your Mean: ");<n>        double myMean;<n>        myMean = in.nextDouble();<n>        System.out ("\n");<n>        if (mean<0)<n>        {<n>            System.out.println("Please enter Mean greater than 0");<n>            in.nextLine();<n>        }<n>        else<n>        {<n>            mean = myMean;<n>            System.out.println(mean + "\n");<n>        }<n><n>    }<n>}<n>

Choices:  A: dry hair B: spreading C: blowing hard D: change direction E: wave wheat<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. the correct answer is D because a wind with wave the wheat on a dry season.<n><n>### <n>The wind is often called "blowing wind". Wind is a fast movement of air from one place to another. The wind carries moisture, dust, smoke, pollen, and other particles. If the wind comes from the sea, it picks up salt particles from the water, making the air salty.<n><n>For example, sea wind is salty.<n>A salty sea wind is also called a "salty wind". <n><n>There are four kinds of winds.<n><n>The 4 kinds of winds are:<n>- The warm wind has less pressure than the cold wind and so it blows faster.<n>- The cold wind has higher pressure than the warm wind and so it blow faster.<n>- Wind that blows from the sea toward the land is called a sea wind.<n>- Wind that comes from the sea will bring moisture with it.<n>- If you want to move things on water quickly, you can use the wind.<n><n>The wind speed is measured in meters. <n><n>Wind speed is the speed at which the wind is moving. <n><n>### Demostraction:<n>The wind direction is a direction that is determined by the direction from which the wind blows.<n><n>The wind blows when you feel the pressure of the air.<n><n>The wind direction is the direction from which the air is blowing.<n>The wind speed is the speed of the air. <n><n>The wind speed changes depending on where you are.<n><n>The wind will blow from east or west. <n><n>The warm wind blows from the east or the west, and the cold wind blows from the north, the south, or the sea.<n><n>The cold wind blows from north, south, or sea.<n><n>The warm wind will blow from the ocean on days with a lot of cloudy weather.<n>When it is sunny, there is no wind, so it is very hot. <n><n>The temperature will be high and the atmosphere will be dry. <n><n>## Dry hair<n>The wind blows from the sea. <n><n>The salt air from the sea makes skin cells more vulnerable to sun damage than water alone, as salt water has less moisture than fresh water.  <n><n>Sea water is rich in salt

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Ice fishing can be done surprisingly far out most winters on what greatest of the Michigan's greats? Choices:  A: pond B: underwater C: aquarium D: lake superior E: body of water<n><n>### Response:		A<n>#### A<n>Answer:A<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Use the above code to write a function below.<n>The input to the function must be "3".<n>The return value will need to be 15.<n>To accomplish this, we simply multiply 3 by 5 (because the problem asks for the answer to be 15).<n><n>####  ____(3)_<n>___()(3)___()____<n>Answer:<n><n>####<n><n>### Insturctions<n>A function to implement the greedy algorithm that is given below and return the value returned from the original.<n><n>### Original:The function takes as input an array, and it return the sum of the elements. Using greedy algorithm, write a program to get the maximum sum possible for the input array.<n><n>#### _****([5])****_<n>1. Create a function named sum() with parameter as an array and return the sum of the values in the input array. And then call the function with input array.<n>2. Initially, sum() can be used to find the maximum sum in the given array.<n>3. The above approach will not work because it is possible that some number cannot be added.<n>4. Hence we have to replace the previous function with new one while iterating on current element in the input array.<n>5. Now, in the new function, the while loop is modified with an if condition.<n>6. If the current value is smaller than the previous value, change the while condition to iterate further with the current array value.<n>7. However, if the current value is larger than the previous value, do not iterate further to that value, simply break the while loop to find the sum with that particular value.<n>8. Finally sum() is used to get the maximum sum from the input array.<n>#### 5<n>Answer:<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>**14630230753277979<n>** 1<n><n>** <n>** 20850073198239646<n>** 1<n>**<n><n><n>### Outputs:<n>    "120479130233544396"<n>#### 120470913025384496<n>Answer:<n><n><n>##
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If there is a stale smell in the air coming from the kitchen, what should one check for the source of the smell? A better option is a bookstore or record store.<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>D does not fit because a vinyl would be a different type of record, like a sheet of vinyl for the kitchen.  C does not fit because a record album is something of the past, and does not fit with contemporary trends. E does not fit because a wall would be the last thing a person would buy.  B would not be a good choice for vinyl, and A would have fewer options.<n><n>### A would be the best out of the few choices given.<n><n>Input:<n><n>My son wants to build his own bookcase. The missing numbers are separated into three parts.<n><n>### Response Example:In this example, there are 3 sets of 3 elements that need to be replaced. So there is one more element which does not exceed the maximum value. Since we know that the missing elements should be 3-element sets, the missing element may only be a 1 or a 2. So the missing element should be either one one the values or 2 or 3.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Mary was a bad girl, but she was always open about that.  People liked her because she was what? Choices:  A: excellent B: fun C: honest D: worthy E: choice<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>Output:<n>#### a<n>Answer: a<n><n>### Input :John wants to eat a delicious steak that weighs 2.25 lbs and is $11.50. What would this cost him? Choices: A: $2.32 B: $<<2.32>>2.32 C: $<<2.65>>2.65 D: $<<2.94>>2.94 E: $<<3.04>>3.04  F: $3.25 G: $3.34 H: $<<3.34>>3.34  I: $3.40 J: $3.50 K: $<<3.50>>3.50  L: $3.61 M: $<<3.61>>3.61  N: $3.75 O: $<<3.75>>3.75  P: $4.00 Q: $<<4.00>>4.00<n><n>### Response :B<n>#### 3.75<n>Answer: 3.75
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The competition was to see who would be the last one the drop the object, the hard part was you had to have your arm extended straight out while what the object? Choices:  A: holding B: lift up C: pick up D: lifting E: hold onto<n><n>### Response:		<n>D or E <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response that appropriately fills the blank or answers the question, below.<n><n>### Rationale: Adam went to the store and paid $56.50. The bill was $56.56. He wrote out a check for $56.55, which was rejected, and he had to draw $0.01 from his account to cover the overdraft. He received a service charge of $0.10<n>for the overdraft.  He wants to write the check and draw from his account at the same time, instead of twice. How much money would he need to have in his account?<n>```Java<n>public static int getAmount(double bill, double tipped, boolean isServiceCharge) {<n>    if (tipped > 0 && isServiceCharge == false) {<n>        return bill<n>    }<n>    else if (!isServiceCharge == true) {<n>        return tipped<n>    }<n>    return 0<n>}<n>```<n>### Answer: 55.80 <n><n>### Explanation: Adam wrote a check for $55.80. At the end of the day he drew $0.10 in service charge.<n><n>### Task: <n>Write a function or procedure that can produce values for 0 to 1,000,000. The function or procedure you write will be  called twice each time. Once when given number is 0 and then when given number is 1,00,001.<n><n>### Input : 0<n>### Function : print("Hello World!")<n>### Output: Hello World!<n><n>### <n>Exercise 3: Writing a Function, Procedure, or Subroutine:<n>```Java<n><n>class Example1 {<n>    private String myName;<n>    private double myAge;           // age is a numeric variable<n><n>    Example1(String name, double age) {   <n>        myName = name;<n>        myAge = age;<n>    }   <n><n>    void showData() {<n>        System.out.println("Hello I am " + myName);<n>        System.out<n>               .println("I am "+ myAge + " years old.");<n>    }    <n>}<n><n>public

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. It says so in black and white.<n><n>### Input-Demonstration: This one makes me go cross-eyed.<n><n>### Rationales: A: A museum exhibit cannot be found in New York City.<n>That is unless you are talking about a museum in the city of New York, but then New York would be the only place on Earth that a mammoth would be found.<n>B: It is very unlikely for a mammoth to be on display in the middle of the city.<n>I know it has happened in the past, but I think it is very rare.<n>C: New York City is in modern times.<n>Mammoths only existed during prehistoric times.<n>D: Natural History museums focus on animals that lived before the time of mankind.<n>So, it would be highly unlikely (and stupid, in my opinion) to put modern animals in there.<n>E: This is where they will find dinosaurs.<n>Not a mammoth. I am sure that if they found a mammoth in a forest they would have been all over it.<n><n>### Answer: B<n><n><https://github.com/thoughtfaucet/thoughtfauceter><n><n>---<n><n>> [![Made with â™¡ by ThoughtFaucet](https://github.com/-/mdcdn/raw/master/-/markdown/logo-32x32.png)](https://github.com/#)

Choices: A) I think we have some trouble before the class begins. B) I think I will not be able to finish this task. C) I was not sure what to do.  D) I will need to check the notes to see.<n><n>### A: I think we have some before problems before the class begins.<n><n>### C: I was not sure what I need to do.<n><n>### B: I think I will not complete this task. F: I do not know if I will be able to finish task.<n><n>### Correct<n>CORRECT: ANSWER: C<n><n>### Grammar Instructions:Grammar Instructions:  Please choose the correct form of the irregular verb in parenthesis. Choices: A: eat B: (eat) C: eat (eat) F: eat D: eat (eat))<n><n>### ANSWER: B<n>#### <n>CAN'T<n><n>### Grammer Instructions:  Choose the verb. Choose the correct the grammar form is. Choices: A. He has been in school for years. B. He was not here last week. C. He is at school since he was six. D. He went to school when he was seven years old.<n>F. He had never been in school until last year<n><n>### A. He has been.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If I have a reception with many people attending, where should I be sure to hold it? Choices:  A: grand casino B: large room C: restaurant D: country club E: lobby<n><n>### Response:		What is the word that goes with each choice?<n>Answer: Choices A and B are both located on Casino Terraces.<n><n>### Input:(2,1)/<<(2,1)/2>> is how many points I get on an exam.  Find the next number in this geometric progression: (1,1,1,1)<n><n>### Response:(1,1,1)/<<(1,1,1/2)>><n><n>### Input  : 3/4 is equivalent to what fraction?<n><n>### Response<n>Answer:<n><n>### Input : Choose 2 numbers to make into a fraction: 2/3<n><n>### Response <n><n>### Input:-5/-4 is equivalent to what number?<n><n>#### -28/<<-28/-4>><n><n>### Response :- 28/<<-4>> is the reciprocal of -4<n><n>### <n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What past time are people engaged in when they are traveling along liquid? Choices: A) $0.50-$20 B) $0+ C) $300-$399 D) $400-$800 E: $900-$1,000<n><n>#### Rationale:<n><n>Answer: B) $0-$300<n><n>### Concluding<n><n>### Question 3:<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Below is an incomplete task. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The jar was plastic, just like most of the stuff in the kitchen.  John preferred glass, and wished he was somewhere else.  Where does he want to be? Choices:  A: cupboard B: anywhere else C: everything D: own home E: garbage dump<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input.There are 200 students in a high school.  There are 16 teachers, each teaching one class of 25 students.  If every teacher has an equal number of students in a single class, how many teachers must we add for each group to have an equal number of students? Choices: One One and  a half Two Three<n><n>### Rationales:A class that has an unequal amount of students, itâ€™s the worst.  25*2=<<25*2=50>>50 students in a class would equal a class with 16 teachers.  So to make each class equal we would add another 7, <n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n>

How much did he spend to cover his purchases?<n>#### A<n><n>Answer: A<n>(54.77-6=<<54.77-$6=54.77>>54.77)<n>

Choices:  A: radio shack B: substation C: cabinet D: television E: desk<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: (C)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following statement.<n><n>### Statement:<n>Cabinet contains TV and also cable.<n><n>### Rationales:(A)<n>Radio Shack doesnt contain TV or cable. It contains a radio. So it does not contain TV or cable.<n>(B)<n>Substation does not include TV or cable.<n><n>(C)<n>Cabinet includes a TV and a cable.<n><n>(D)<n>Desk includes TV and also cable. <n><n>(E)<n>For Desk it is unknown if a cable goes with TV. <n><n>Since (C)->(true) and (D)->(false) and (E)->(false) and only (C)->(true).<n><n>#### true<n>Answer: true<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Answer the following statement. Choices:(A) True (B) False (C) True (D) False (E) Unknown<n><n>### Statements:<n><n>Cabinet includes TV and also cable and (D) and cabinet includes TV.<n><n>### Choices: (A) Radio Shack doesnt include TV.<n>(B) Substation doesnt include TV.<n><n>(C)(D)(E): Substation includes (D) and (E) is unknown.<n><n>### False:<n>Answer: (False)<n><n>### Input(1): What device uses a 1.2 volt battery? Choices: <n><n>### Response(1): (Laser Point)<n><n>### Statment(1): (L) Laser Pointer uses a 1.3 volt battery.<n><n>### Response (2): (C) Cell Phone uses a 1.5 volt battery.<n><n>#### False<n>Answer: (False, Laser Pointer: False, Cell Phone: True)<n><n>### Response1: (B)<n><n>### Rationale1: Cellphone doesnt have a 1.2 volts battery. <n><n>#### 1.3<n>Answer: 1.3<n><n>### Response2: (False)<n>(C)<n>Because the statement that I made about Cell Phone (C) is False, that is I gave Cell Phone a False response I should have selected (False)<n><n>#### (E)<n><n>Answer: (False/Unknown)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where is a business restaurant likely to be located? Choices:  A: town B: at hotel C: mall D: business sector E: yellow pages<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  A: B  at hotel  C: D E:<n><n>### Input:(Sentence)A good manager should be open to suggestions from their employees.<n><n>### Response:(Sentence) The best managers I've ever had have been open to suggestions from their subordinates.<n><n>### Input:'I enjoy spending my free time reading the newspaper.'.<n><n>### Response:'I enjoy reading the newspaper each day after returning from work.'<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: costly B: captive C: contained D: paying E: caught<n><n>### Response:		<n>Captive<n><n>### Response Rationale:<n>As the word in sentence is Captive which means to capture.<n><n>### Input(2):The first two letters of the name of a famous mathematician were a and d.  What two-letter word was formed by adding one more letter to the letters of a and d?  Choices:  A:"dandy"  B:"dand?" C:"candy" D:"dad" E:"decoy"<n><n>### Response(2):<n>Dandy<n><n>### Response (2) Rationale:<n>The first two letters of a famous Mathematician name is "A" and "D".<n>Then the two letters name is Dandy.<n><n>### IMPORTANT<n><n>#### RULE 1<n><n>- A question has exactly 1 choice that is correct.<n><n>- A question can have more than one choices but only one of them is correct.<n><n>Examples 1 :<n><n>How much did he paid a kilo of nuts<n><n>- 36 is a correct choice.<n><n>- Adam bought 3 kilos of nutts so 3 * 12 = 36<n><n>The other choices are incorrect choices.<n><n>Examples(2) :<n><n>How many hours does he spend the gym?<n><n>- 4 is a correct choice. <n><n>- He spent 80 minutes in the gym daily and 80 times 60 minutes per day he does gym.<n><n>240 minutes is correct answer.<n><n>What two-letter word was added to the letters of "a and d"?<n><n>- Dandy is correct choice.<n><n>- First two letters of "a and "d" is AD.<n><n>Then the other two letters are dad.<n><n><n>#### RULES<n><n>1. A question only has 1 correct choice.<n><n>2. You answer a question if you use only the correct answers.<n><n>3. A question has not more than one correct answer but it can have more than one choice.<n><n>4. Question can have more than one correct choice.<n><n>5. You are able to determine if a choice is correct or not by using the words in the sentence.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Jame's bare feet were burned as he walked, because the sunshine had made the surface hot.  Where might he have been? Choices:  A: disneyland B: snow C: windowsill D: street E: summer<n><n>### Response:		Answer B.<n><n>### Explain:It must have been hot outside because the sun was burning his feet and made the dirt hot.<n>

Choices:  A: gain weight B: late for work C: heartburn D: bad breath E: early for work<n><n>### Response:		<n>"He got heartburn"<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Spoof is a word that means â€œjoker," "trickster." Use the words in the passage to choose the appropriate definitions.<n>What is the meaning of using the word "Spoof"?<n>### The word "spoof" may have different meanings depending on its use and the context.<n>In a literal sense, "spoof" is slang for an overweight clown.<n>However, in a literary sense, "spoOF" is slang for a prank intended to make a fool out of someone.<n>If you tell a joke that "spoofs" the other person, you are intentionally humiliating them.<n><n>If a TV show airs a fake interview, or if an actor in a play pretends to be a famous politician, it's probably a "spoof" as it attempts to discredit the person's reputation.<n>If someone uses words in an unrelated context, it becomes a joke, and the person using it is a "spoof."<n>If you are a comedic writer who frequently uses words to humiliate people who think they are smarter than they really are, you must be a clown.<n>### <n><n>### Input<n>The man was eating and when he looked at his time, it read 12:40, so he rushed to catch his flight. He was early and he ordered the same thing.<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>The man wanted to catch his flight<n>He did not want to be late.<n><n>#### The meaning of the input is that the man was eating<n>#### The definition of early is "to be quicker or earlier than someone or something"<n>#### The definition of Spoof is "an act of humiliation where someone is treated differently than they really are"<n><n>### Output:<n>The man was eaten, but did not want to be joked about.  He rushed when he looked for his time to get to his work on time.<n>He was early and he ordered himself the very same item.<n>#### The meaning of Spoof is to not use humorous words in a context that the speaker did not intend nor had ever intended<n><n><n><details><summary><strong>Solution</strong><img src="https://raw

Choices:  A. Write clean code. B. Maintain clean code. C. Write unclean code. D. Maintain unclean code.<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: "A good programmer knows how write clean code" is anothers way to say a good programmer knows how write code.<n>Rationales: Clean Code is another way to say:<n>```<n>The Code written does what it supposed to do and can easily be understood by others. (e.g. other programmers, other members of the team, other who doesn't know the code)<n>```<n>#### Write clean code<n>##### Explanatation:<n>Clean Code Means that it can easily be understood by other programmers, members of the team and others who doesn't know and understand the code.<n><n>###Input: Clean code is written with a variety of methods, techniques, and tools that programmers use to make code better.  Which of the following are ways for a programmer to write clean code?<n><n>### 1. Make sure code does its intended job. <n>2. Make sure the code can be maintained by others.<n>3. Write functions that do exactly one thing and do it well.<n>4. Use comments judiciously so that the documenting part of programming isn't forgotten.<n>5. Avoid redundancy by using meaningful names for variables and functions.<n><n>### Response<n>```<n>1. Make sure each code do exactly what it intended to do.<n>2. Make sure every code can be maintained by other programmers.<n>3. Write only one function that does its intended and well.<n>4. Avoid redundancies<n>5. Use unique variables and functions by defining good variable and function names<n>```<n>#### Explanation<n>**1.** Make sure each code do each what it is intended to do.<n>**2.** Make sure code can easily to maintain by other members of a team.<n>**3.** Write functions that do exactly their intended and well.<n>**

(Possibilities:<n>If 2/3 of bats are blind, it doesn't mean all bats are blind. Do you think the theatre is worth the extra cost?<n><n>### Demand:<n>Input: $15 is much more then $10 which makes watching a movie at the theatre worth it even more.<n>Rationales: It costs more to go to movies in theatres<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Instuctions:<n>Write a response that provides a reason in favor of or in opposition of the following statement.<n><n>### Statement:<n>The average American worker does not earn a living wage.<n><n># Test1.2<n>Write a response that supports or denies the following statement.<n># Statement:<n>If you can walk across the floor 20 times, then you can walk across the room 20 times.<n><n># Statement:No<n><n>### Demosition:<n>Rationales<n>If you can you don't need to ask<n>If you don't need one time then you can just go.<n>So if you can one time you don't need it at all<n>So if it takes 20 times to walk 10 meters then just one time is more then one 10 meter walk<n>#### B<n>Answer:A<n><n>### Instutions
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What group of musicians will include someone playing the cello? Choices:  A: ocean B: symphony C: band D: music store E: music shop<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n>#### Input:  A<n><n>### Response<n><n>#### Input:B<n><n>### Response <n><n>#### Input:C<n><n>### Response  <n><n>#### Input:D<n><n>### Response   <n><n>#### Input:E<n><n>### Response      <n><n>#### Input:  E
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Stanley had a dream that was very vivid and scary. He had trouble telling it from what? Choices:  A: reality B: imagination C: dreamworker D: nightmare E: awake<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input2:Nathaniel has a big backpack full of video games. He had trouble carrying it. He had to carry it because? Choices:<n>B: it was too big<n>C: all his friends wanted to see it<n>D: he has to<n>E: he had to be at the movies<n><n>### Response2:D<n><n>### Input3:Ben was able to read a book that was extremely difficult. He had trouble because to? Choices:<n>D: he can't see very well<n>A: it was too hard<n>C: he was busy<n>B: he needed some help<n>E: it was not interesting<n>#### 60<n>Answer:30<n><n>1960<n><n>### Instructions<n><n>```sh<n># Install docker<n>$ curl -fsSL https://get.docker.com -o docker-ce-stable.zip<n>$ unzip docker-ce-stable*.zip<n>$ sudo mv docker-ce /usr/local/bin/<n>$ sudo echo "export PATH=/usr/local/bin\$PATH" >> ~/.bashrc<n>$ sudo source ~/.bashrc;<n><n><n>### Run docker command<n>```<n>$ sudo docker pull mcr.microsoft.com/media/python:3.7.14-latest<n>Using default tag: python:3.7.7-wheezy_latest<n>latest: Pulling from mcr.microsoft.us/media/python... <n>Digest: sha256:0cebe49f0998924e57072b0baf90b69e83c572e76484e8714786c608ebd83087<n>Status: Downloaded newer image for python:3.7-wheezieser_latest<n>Successfully built python:3.7:2cb1d992898d<n>```<n>```sh<n># Pull Docker image mcr.microsoft.azurewebsites.net/mangoprima/pycharm<n>$ sudo docker pull https://mcr.microsoft.com hwm-2300.azurewebsites.ru:5000/mangopr3ma/pych

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:A person lived in my what? Choices:  A: demonstration B: conference C: building D: garage E: mouth<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n>Answer: B

They each share protein, fats, and carbohydrates.<n><n>### Response2-<n>When a waiter serves a slice of apple pie, what is he giving the customer?<n><n>### Respones-<n>This can be interpreted as the waiter is serving a piece to the customer. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Which region has the most famous temple? Choices:  A: child's hand B: the last straw C: hobby shop D: end of line E: toy store<n><n>### Response:		 answer one of the choice<n><n>### Answer: E<n><n>### Discussion:<n>1. The answer is 'e' because she lost the kite when she reached the end of the kite. Which means that the spool had no more string.<n><n>### Rules to follow:<n>1. Check what the instructions says.<n>2. Try to answer the instruction you received.<n>3. If in any way you find a mistake in you answer or in the input, don't continue to the next response. The answer is always the question.<n><n>---<n><n>### Input A:The last letter the alphabet is ______.<n>Answer A: Z<n><n>### Instructions: <n>Input: It is said that "An image is worth a thousand words.". Choose the correct answer. <n>A) The above statement uses over-reaching language. <n><n>B) The above statement is an idiom.<n><n>C) The above statement is a rhetorical question.<n><n>D) The above statement tells an anecdote.<n><n>Answer: C<n><n>---<n><n>---<n><n><n><n>### Input B:<n>Input: When a dog has rabies it ______.<n>Answer B: bark loudly<n><n>### Instrections:<n>Input: You're not the smartest person in the world. You're ____.<n>Answer: A) dumber<n><n>1. Dumber is the sentence after the main sentence<n>2. Which means that B is the correct answer<n><n>---<n><n>Input:<n>```<n>The last letter of the alphabet is<n>z<n>```<n><n>Output:<n>```<n>z<n>```<n>Input:<n>```bash<n>echo "the last letter "<n>```<n>Output:<n>```bash<n>the last letter<n>```<n><n>```bash<n>echo the last "a" is "b"<n>```<n><n>Output<n>```bash<n>the<n>last<n>a<n>is<n>b<n>```<n><n>---<n>Input:<n>```python<n>print("The last letter of the")<n>```<n>Output: <n>```<n>The last<n>letter<n>```<n>---<n>Input: <n>```swift<n>println("The last letter of ")<n>```<n>Output: The last letter of<n><n>---<n>Input<n>```java<n>System.out.println("The last letter ")<n>```<n>Output<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:East coast areas such as Florida are found where? Choices:  A: florida B: denmark C: united states D: map E: california<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Input<n>Choices: A: florida B C D A: florida C: united states<n><n>### Response<n>E: california<n>

Choices:  A: happy B: smile C: calm D: entertainment E: relaxation<n><n>### Response:		I will answer that in a moment<n><n>### Rationale:The two letter choices we see here are "AB" and "BC", which can be represented by a string of length 2.<n>If the two letters are "AB", then we could have string of length 2 "AB", which would be the same as the answer choice "A".<n>If the two letters "AC", "AD", etc are not in the answer list, then we must be seeing "AB" or "BC" and we must be seeing an even string of length 2<n>I've seen multiple strings like these as well, all even strings of length 2<n><n>### Input:(A=happy B=smile C=calm D=entertainment E=relaxation<n>)<n><n>### Input<n>1. "My teacher said that she saw a snake on her yard during  a thunderstorm"<n>2. "I saw a snake on my yard when it was dark"<n><n>### Input1 (sentence 1)<n><n>### Rnage:I saw a snake in my yard during a thunderstorm<n><n>### Rationales:I'll just do it in the input. We're given two sentences with the same context.  <n>```<n>context: The  weather was nice, and you had an idea about planting your own garden.  However,  you heard there were snakes in the area and didn't like the idea of that.  After a while you realized you would be taking a big risk, or maybe it was all in your head.  Well, one day you were looking around your yard, because you were really bored,  and when you looked up, you saw a snake on your yard during a thunder storm.<n>```<n>### Input2 (sentence 2)<n><n>### Range: I saw a snake in the yard during a thunderestorm<n><n>### Range Rationales: I'll just do it again.<n><n>### Input3<n>```<n>In this sentence I heard two things.  There was an incident involving an argument with a neighbor,  it happened during  the day.  There was another incident involving a thunderstorm,  and those events occurred at the same time.  Finally, as an outside detail  an elephant was also present, but happened earlier

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:John loved competing because he was very competitive.  He liked being about to divide people into what categories? Choices:  A: winners and losers B: perform better C: might win D: losses E: enemies<n><n>### Response:		 John was competitive because he wanted to be seen as a winner and that was probably why he liked people to be divided into categories of winners and losers. He like to be seen as a competitor and to divide people into winners and losers could be one way for him to do that. He liked competing and he loved the feeling of being a winner. He wanted to be placed in the category of a winner.<n><n>### Input 2:  Iris was feeling sick but she decided to go to her friend's house to keep from vomiting while she slept there. Which of these does not need to happen before she can go to her friend' story house? A: The house should be empty B: The house should be washed C: The house should not be dirty D: She should not be sick<n>#### A<n><n>### Dem:  Iris needs to go to her friend who had a clean house because Iris will be sleeping there.<n><n>* She needs to go to her friends house who had a clean house so that does not need to happen first.<n><n>### Answer: A<n><n>Input:Which state is the best for a person to live in if they do not like extreme cold or extreme heat?<n><n>Input: A person's favorite color is blue.<n><n>Input: In the town of Caveat the majority of residents love cheese.<n><n>Input: It is not healthy for a person to eat unhealthy snack foods in heavy amounts.<n><n>Input: The town of Moxie is in a river.<n><n>Input:  I love to eat huevos rancheros.<n><n>Input: Many people in the world want to go to space.<n><n>Input: Pineapple does not taste good on hamburgers.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. Hawaii is good because it is not extreme in any way. It does not get to hot and it does not get to cold. It has a variety of climate types throughout the state.<n>2. In Hawaii it is more humid than in California because Hawaii is more humid which means that rainfall is more frequent.<n>3. You could move to Alaska and be cold but it is nice climate to be cold. It is good for most people because nobody wants to be hot or cold all the time.<n>4. In New York City
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What could prevent someone from buying chistmas presents? Choices:  A: happiness B: lack of money C: stress D: relief E: exhiliration<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:  A

She wanted to be able to relax on it at the end of the day.  How many legs does the coffee table have? Choices: A: Many B: One C: Two D: Three<n><n>### Rationales:A leg is a part of a piece of furnishing that supports its structure.<n>A coffee table is intended to be used as a work surface or surface to put a lap.<n>Therefore, it is expected that a coffee table would have multiple support legs.<n>One leg is required to maintain a safe and functional structure to support the weight of its surface.<n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### InputA table can be a place for eating or placing cards.  What type of wood is it made out of? Choices: A. Oak B. Pine C. Teak D. Willow<n><n>### Rationale:A table can be a piece of furnishing, and a wood is a type of tree.  Therefore, a table is made from wood, which can be wood that comes from a tree.<n>These four types of wood listed above are all types of wood.<n>A. Oak<n>Oak is a common type of hardwood that occurs throughout North America and Europe.<n>B. Pine<n>Pine is a softwood that is found in North America, Europe, and North Africa.<n>C. Teak<n>Teak grows in Asia.  It is a tropical hardwood.<n>D. Willow<n>Willow is a tree with branches called twigs.<n>It originates in northern temperate regions.<n>So Willow can be found in North America, Asia, and Europe.<n>We conclude that the correct answer is D, because all of the trees are found in those regions.<n>#### E<n>Answer: E<n><n>### Input A: Which of this types of clothing is warmest for winter? Choices: A) Winter coat B) Jeans C) Gloves D) Sock<n><n>### Rationle:Choices: A) Winter Coat, which is called a coat, a hat, socks, and a scarf are all types of clothing.<n>B) Jeans, which

Choices:  A: disorientation B: due to C: meeting new people D: getting somewhere E: relocation<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input<n>Traveling underwater presents many difficulties, such as decreased visibility causing disorientation, as well as the difficulty of meeting new people while under the sea. The water at its deepest point is also as far away from where you are as you can go, which makes it impossible to relocate.<n><n>### Answer<n>"Traveling underwater" is being confused with "going scuba diving". Scuba diving causes a lot of the disorientation and the difficulty of meeting new poeple is the whole point of the activity, rather than its drawback as you may have assumed.<n><n>### InputTraveling down a mountain on a bicycle presents the dangers of a collision with what types of objects? Choices:  All of the following choices are incorrect except: A: cars B: deer C: glaciers D: motorbikes E: sheep F: trees G: wild animals<n><n>### Response<n>A<n><n>### InputMountain biking is a sport that is very hazardous since it puts you at risk of colliding with what types of objects Choices:  All except: A: glaciers B: motorbikes C: sheep D: trees E: wild animals<n><n>ResponseGlaciers are not what you commonly encounter while mountain biking but some people use them as landmarks to help them navigate difficult terrain and rocky terrain.<n><n>### RationalesMotorcycles arenâ€™t the first thing to come to mind. It also isnâ€™t a thing you donâ€™t associate with mountain biking, but colliding with one wouldnâ€™t be good.<n><n>### Choices:  All but: A: sheep B: trees C: wild animals<n><n>AnswerB: Wild Animals<n><n>### Choice:<n>A<n>1>2>3<n>4>5<n>6<n><n>### RationaleThe first two answers should be the biggest ones, they contain the greatest number of digits.<n>The last two answers are the ones you care about most but they have the smallest number of digits.<n><n>The last answer has 3 digits so it takes 3 guesses before it gives the same answer.<n><n>### ResponseGiven:<n>1.834<n><n>### Rough Answer<n>9/2- 9/3 = 9/6<n>

People wait for their train to leave the train station so they can talk to someone whom they havenâ€™t seen in a while.<n>#### Choice E: Airport<n>Rationales: Travelers pass through these telephone booths before they depart or return to their flight.<n><n>#### <n>Answer: E:<n><n>### Input :There are 1000 dogs. 50% of the dog owners are women. 1 out of 10 female dog owners are veterinarians. What percent of all women that own dogs are veterinarians?<n>### Response<n>Rationales: 50%*1=<<50%*1=.5>>0.5 out of 1000 owners are veterinarian<n>So 1000*50%*.5=<<1000*0.5*50=25>>25 out of 1,000 dog owners are veterianarians.<n>1/25=<<1/25=.04>>0.04<n><n>#### <n><n>Answer:.04<n><n>### Input  :  What's 24 to the power of 6? Speaking words will not transport a person and neither will believing in God or dancing together.<n><n>#### RESOLVED<n><n>### Input :What enables most people to travel? Choices:  A: wedding B: tennis C: closet D: left foot E: house<n><n>### Response:		ANSWER A: WEDDING<n>### Rationale: Weddings require white shoes.<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>#### A: White: Wedding<n>#### B: White: Tennis<n>#### C: White: Closet<n>#### D: White: Left Foot<n>#### E: White: House<n><n>### Response Choices:<n>#### SAT: A<n>#### MCAT: E<n>#### GRE: B<n>#### GMAT: C<n>#### CAT: C<n>#### ACT: D<n>#### ISEE: D<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What place of work might you find a hairpin? Choices:  A: hair salon B: hair of woman C: barber shop D: pincushion E: woman's hair<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demolition:<n><n>

How much did his purchuses cost?<n>#### Demostration<n>In the demo, the user asks the user to think of a number, the user thinks of some number and the program determines if they thought of what it expected by comparing to the number it is actually expecting. To do so, they compare the two inputs to determine if there are the same (not really in this case).<n><n><n><n>#### Rationales<n>Since the question is "How much did his purchases" cost, the rationales would be:<n><n>What he paid for the nuts is $36+$20=$56<n>How much did they cost is 3*$12+$2.5*$8=$56<n><n>The rationales show what they think and the answer is the correctness<n><n><n><n>### ASSERTION:<n>If one of the choices is wrong, then the program should return the answer in red and explain the error.<n>If there is only one correct choice, then the program should not return anything, and the correct choice should be shown in green. If there is no correct choice, then the correct choice should be given in purple.<n><n>### Response<n>#### Input:Johns goes to the gulm thrx 3 times a weak. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:When would you be able to see your reflection in a piece of wood? How long will it take me to cycle 68km?<n><n>Output:3.5 hours<n><n>#### Rationals:<n>Based on each answer choice's question and your given answer.<n><n>Output:<n><n>Input: Sally is 60 km from Toronto and Steve is 55 km from Toronto.  They are traveling to a restaurant in the city by car. They both leave at the same time from their homes.  How far apart are they after 2 hours?<n><n>#### Rational:<n>Distance = rate * time<n><n>Time = distance / rate<n><n>Sally = 60 km / 60 min<n><n>Steve = 55 km / 60 minute<n><n>So 2 hours gives Sally = 60 * 2 = <<2*4=56>>55 and Steve 2 hours = 55*2 =<55*2=110>>110<n><n>Distance = rate * (or =) time<n><n>So Steve = Sally * 1<n><n>So Sally - 60km <==>>55 * 2 =  <<55*2= 110>>100 and Steve = Sally * <<55*2>><n><n>Their distance are the same so they are 55km away after 2 hours.<n>#### Rational:You can also calculate this distance based off how many kms each person can travel in a given amount of time.<n><n>Input: 1 gallon of gas can run a car 15 miles 60 miles or 100 miles. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where is basketball court likely to be outdoors? Choices:  A: personal B: special C: shiny D: rare E: irregular<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:  They were shiny<n>#### Shiny<n>Answer: Shiny<n><n>### Input : You have a chance of winning first place in a spelling bee.  How many times do you have to spell a word correctly and it be wrong? Choices: 1: 6 2: 15 3: 16 4: 26<n><n>### Response :<n>Rationales: There is more than one way to get an incorrect answer:<n><n>1. Start with the first word.  There are 54 letters.  With each letter you can get one of 4 options.  Thus, 54 choose 1 or 54 choose 2 = 206583 or 206590 if you count 83 or 90<n><n>2. Start with the second word.  It's less.  Choose 4 letters of 52 so 52 choose 4 is 27239<n><n>3. Start with the third word.  This one is more than the other 2, 100,00301<n><n>4. Start with the last word.  The same reasoning.<n><n>#### 0<n>Answer: There is no option to make 6 mistakes in a row.<n><n>### Input  (Continued from input 3)<n><n>### Response  (Continued):<n><n>#### 4<n>  Answer: 4<n>### Input:You can get paid to make coffee or tea.  If you make 10 cups of coffee, how much does it cost to make one cup of coffee? Choices: 5 4 3 2 1 0<n>### Response: <n>Rationales: Each cup you make should cost 1/10 of what you made in total.<n>5. 1/10 = <<1/10=5>>5<n>4. 1/15 = <<1/15=0>>0<n>1. 1/1 = <<1/1=0.0>><n><n>#### 0.0<n>Answer: 0.0<n><n>### Question: The store sells hot dogs. Each hot dog should be on the $5 $4 menu when the store is busy or on the $3 $2 menu when
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The old man was retired and liked the simple things, he would do crossword puzzle every morning simply just to do what? Choices:  A: you're bored B: pass time C: relax D: mentally challenged E: win<n><n>### Response:		I picked the option "You're justified in your choice"<n><n>#### E<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input"The person likes the simple things, he will do crossword puzzle for the benefit of A.B. or"Choices:  A: pass time B: mental challenge C: winning  D: to do it every morning  <n><n>### Response:"I picked C and the correct answer is E"<n><n>#### D<n>Answer: D<n>

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The man was cleaning clothes for his date, what was he looking to achieve?
