Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where in a town would you put your shed? Choices:  A: next to the house B: keeping things in C: backyard D: farm yard E: ranch<n><n>### Response:		The answer is D.<n><n>#### 7:<n>Answer: D: farm yard<n><n>### [7: Write the number 17 in words.<n><n>### Answer:Seventeen<n><n>### [8: Write the number in words.<n><n>#### Thirty-eight:<n>Answer: Thirty-eight<n><n>### [9:  Write the number in words:<n><n>#### Sixty-two:<n>Answer: Sixty-two<n><n>### [10: Write the number in digits:<n><n>#### 92<n>Answer: 92<n><n>### [Lesson 9: Write your own version of the song below.<n><n><n>### [A. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If you're traveling along a highway what item made of paper can you use to find your way? One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. Choices: 1.All positive and negative integers 2.All positive integers only 3.All negative integers only 4.Neither positive nor negative integers<n><n>### Response:(4) :<n>Neither positive nor negative numbers, since it means "all integers", including 0.<n><n>### Input:"Is the following equation true? x+5=x-3. A: False B: True" :<n><n>### Response (True) :<n>The expression in question is not equal to 1. This is because the two expressions do not have the same number of values.<n>The expression in question evaluates to zero, i.e.,<n>(x+5)â€“5=0<n>(x-x)=0<n>Thus we have two expressions with the same number of values but unequal values.<n>Therefore the equation is false.<n><n>### What is the correct comparison for the value of 7 to the value of 10?<n>	A. 7 < 10. B. 7 > 10. C. 7 = 10. D. It is unknown whether or not 7 = 1<n><n>### Response("C") :<n>Answer choices C and D were incorrect because they did not use the symbols > and <

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		Input:What do humans take it in while breathing?<n>Option A: * Lungs and diaphragm<n>Option B: * Oxygen<n>Option C: * Air<n>Option D: * Open throat<n>Option E: * Abdominal muscles<n>Answer: * Oxygen<n><n>### Input::There are 3 planes: A: small planes that cost $150 to fly B: medium planes that cost $200$2000 to fly C: large planes that cost $350$0to fly.  If a plane's length is 1.5 times the cost then how are a plane with a 15 foot length classified?<n>### Response:A: B: Small<n>B: Medium<n>C: Large<n><n>Answer: B: Medium<n><n>### Input:(2,5,-1)<n><n>### Response:(4,0,3)<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where is a lion likely to live? Choices:  A: veldt B: ocean C: savannah D: africa E: jungle<n><n>### Response:		Choices: Choices: B C E Only<n>Answer: Only<n><n>### Instructions:The following statements describe what a person should or should not do. Write a response that accurately indicates whether each action is recommended or not.<n><n>### Input 1:Don't swim in cold water unless you are warm and dry.<n><n>### Response 1:Choices: Recommended Not recommended<n>Answer: Not Recommended<n><n>### Input<n>Don't open the door to people you don't know<n><n>### Response<n>Choices: Choices:(Recommend or Not recommend<n>Answer: Recommend<n><n>### Instructiions:The following statements describe attributes of a person or entity. Write a response that correctly describes who the statement is intended for.<n><n>### Description 1:Ingrid loves to sleep in. Choices: A: her parents (or guardians) B: the students who live near her C: herself<n><n>### Input Description 1:Ingle loves to sleep in..<n><n>### Response Description 1:Choices A: Choices: A B C Her<n><n>### Question answer Description 1:Answers: C, Self<n><n>### Description:2 Choices: A: a cat B: her house<n><n>Input Description:2:A: A B: Self<n><n>### Response description:2:Choices: A B C D E F Only<n><n>### Input description: 3 Choices: A: the park B: the playground C: the mall<n><n>Input description:3:A: A B C D<n><n>### Response Descriptions:Choices: Choice: A<n><n>### Instrumentation:<n>Answer:<n><n>### Instagram Description:<n>Answer description 2: Choices: a b c d<n><n>### Response Instagram:<n>Answer Instagram: Choices: A: A B<n><n>### Description #:4<n><n>### Instractions:Input: 4 Choices: A: B: C: D: E: Only<n><n>## # Description 5<n><n>## Instractions:Description 5: <n><n>### Response to description - input 5:Choices: A: A: Choices:<n><n>### Description-input:<n>Answer input 5: Choices
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Everybody raised a drink and cheered, they were doing what? Choices:  A: were thirsty B: toasting C: getting drunk D: refreshment E: celebrating<n><n>### Response:		Choice (E)<n><n><n>### Input:"Good boy"<n><n>###Response:<n><n>###Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question: What is "good boy's" attitude? Choices: A: polite B: sad C: berserk D: playful E: cheerful<n>###Response:"Good boy", whose name is Charm, is quite playful and he is happy to be petted and fed.<n>###Instruction:"Good boy"<n>###Response: "good boy" - I suppose the owner can pet/feed him.<n>###Rationale: the "good boy" refers to the owner.<n>###Instructions:"Sandy, the dog, is good boy."<n>###Response:"sandy, the dog,is good boy".<n>###Rationale:"(whoever)" refers  to "the dog", not the owner. The dog is not a person. He can't be good. The owner can.<n>###Rationales: Sandy is the dog. Dog refers to a boy.<n><n>###Instrucation: Good<n><n>###Rational: the Good part refers to what was said about Sandy<n><n>###Instuction:Good <n><n>###Rationale "Good at what?", so he is good at what he does, and he does the things mentioned<n><n>###Instution: Good boy<n>###Rationale, because he had a good dog in "Good boy"<n><n><n>###Instraction: "Good boy!"<n><n>###Ratioanal:"Good boy" is a common way used to say "wow you did well, i like it, you are good at it"<n><n>###Insraction:The dog is a good boy because he knows his tricks, he listens to what i tell him  and he is good.<n><n>###Rationel:He is good because he is obedient, he listens to commands and he is happy.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. Choices:  A: advertisement B: magazine C: store D: web page E: bus<n><n>### Response:		Advertisements tend to showcase in-store and web page.<n>In store, is a physical place.<n><n>Also, I will add an example for the bus.<n><n>Bus(In store):<n>Bus is shown in store for the customers to see in real life.<n><n>Bus(On advertisements):<n>Bus is being shown in advertisements to persuade customers to buy it.<n><n>Web page:<n>Web page is an electronic version of a magazine.<n><n>Web page (In store):<n>Web page is shown on-site to inform customers what are the new products.<n><n>Web page(On Advertisements):<n>Web page is being advertised to persuade customers to use it.<n><n><n>### Input<n>It costs $100.10 to fill up a 12-gallon gas tank with gasoline.  An additional 3 cu.ft are allowed for free.  Find the cost for 3 extra gallons<n><n>### Response<n>It costs $18.18 to fill up a 4 additional gallon tank<n><n>$100.1 = 12($0.1) + 3(0) = $100.09<n><n>$$100.06-17 = >>$100.006-17=16.464$$ This is incorrect because you take off $17 on the left side, but don't take off $17.01$ on the right side. That means it should be $100.5$.<n><n>You take $17*100=>>$17*10=1700$$ but the answer is $16.46$.<n><n>### Instructions<n>For the following sets of numbers, determine if one subtotal is greater, less or equal to another.<n><n>|1. 242, 255, 189, 180|<n>|2. 1005, 833, 803, 605| <n><n>|3. 265, 391, 304|<n><n>#### 1<n><n>189 is greater than 180<n><n>Answer 1<n><n>### Instuctions<n>Find three consecutive prime numbers

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: spinning wheel B: on a ladder C: hospital bed D: legroom E: grand piano<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Demostration:<n>This answer is to show the rational for the answer provided.<n>Input: A patient is taken to the hospital in an ambulance.  The weight of the patient and the vehicle together is 730 kilograms.  What is the average density of the patient?<n>Rationales : 730/2 =<<730/2=365>>365 and the average density of the vehicle 1000kg/4 =<<1000kg=250>>250<n>So the average density of 365 and 250 is 1.8<n>#### 18<n>Answer: 18<n><n>### Input : How did the Vikings die? Choices: 1.  Drowned when they forgot where they had been on their trip. 2. Killed during a battle. 3. Died of disease. 4. Starved to death. 5. Froze to death <n><n>### Response :<n>#### 1<n>Answer : 1<n><n>## Output : If a boat traveled a distance of 2 miles down river, how many miles did it travel upriver?<n><n>### Demstoration : Input : A boat travels two miles downstream.  Its speed is $70\tfrac{2}{3}$ miles an hour.  The speed of the current is $5\tfrac{4}{15}\sqrt{5}$ miles an hour.<n><n>Rationales : Travelled 2 downstream $2=6\tfrac{23}{216}$ miles <n><n>Speed of boat $(70\tfrac{17}{216})$ miles/an hour<n><n>Speed of stream $(5\tfrac{15}{216})$<n><n>Speed of stream/speed of boat $(5\tfrac{23} {216} / 70\tfrac{99}{2} = <<5\tfrac{2} {15} / 70 =<<5/70>>$ The answer $6\tfrac{2}  {15}$<n><n>#### 6/70<n>Answer : 6/70

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:John is a human who is in a wheelchair due to an accident.  Where would he go to get to the third floor of his apartment building? Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices:  A: Space Shuttle B: Detroit C: Stairs D: Downtown E: Elevator<n><n>### Input<n>Your uncle owns a small business.  It has been open for 18 years and he's on the brink of going bankrupt.  How long has the business been open for?  Choices: A: 12 years B: 9 years C: 5 years D: 16 years E: 20 years<n><n>### Rationales (Based on the information provided and the given choices)<n>#### 16<n>Answer: 16<n><n>### Input John is on a road trip.  He wants to get from Miami, FL to New York, NY.  How far is it?  Choices:  A) 248 miles B) 224 miles C) 280 miles D) 268 miles E) 341 miles<n><n>#### 341<n>Answer: 341<n><n>### Input There is a small island that a community lives on.  There are 53 people in the community.  The population is growing at 5% a year. How many people are there in the community, in 5 years?<n><n>#### 77<n>Answer: 77<n><n>### Input Dad loves sports!  He loves baseball, basketball, football, and tennis.  Of these 4 sports, which does he enjoy most?  Choices: B: Baseball C: Football D: Basketball E: Tennis<n><n>####  D baseball<n>Answer: Option B<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:One might find theirs open, with the letters that had been delivered stolen. Choices:  A: front door B: newspaper C: post office D: package E: mail box<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A)<n><n>B)<n>C)<n><n>D)<n><n>E)<n><n>####<n>Answer: D<n><n>### Input<n>```<n><n>1. Input: A string that a user wants to create a word cloud based on. Output: A word cloud based on the string.Rationales: Input:A string that a user wants Output:A word cloud based on the user's string. The string will be divided into sentences and words within each sentence will count as one word.So the count of words is the sum of the count of words in each sentence.<n>```<n>String: Hello John, we are friends.<n><n>Letter in count of words<n>Hello 1<n>John 1<n>, 2<n>we 1<n>are 1<n>friends 2<n>```<n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n>## Questions<n><n>### Task: Complete the code.<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>array = ["Hello John", "world", "are", "friends", "How"]<n>```<n>Your answer:<n>```<n>[<n>    {<n>        "sentences": [<n>            "Hello John, world"<n>        ],<n>        "words": [<n>            "world"<n>        ]<n>    },<n>    {<n>        sentences": [<n>            "are friends",<n>            "How"<n>        ],<n>    },<n>]<n>```<n>#### world<n>Answer: 1<n>### Task:Complete the code.<n><n><n>### Demand<n><n>#### 8<n>Answer: 8<n><n>### Task<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>```<n>string = "Hello I don't like you"<n>```<n>#### You<n>Answer: 2 <n><n>### Demote<n><n>### Demons<n><n>### <n>### Input<n>Input: A user needs to be able to find the value of a variable called var1. Choices:  A: back pocket B: meeting C: drug store D: home E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>- Meeting<n><n>### Rationales<n>A to E notepads are small, the meeting notes are large.<n><n>### Input:- Do you want to use a notepad or an iPad/laptop? Choices:  B: laptop C: iPad<n><n>### Response:- iPad<n><n>##<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Rubric:Write a response that appropriately answers the question below<n><n>### Input : Which is the largest element of a three-digit number? One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. However, in recent years it has been exploited for its resources such as gold, cocoa, coffee and more.  The human presence has disrupted this ecosystem, as we have often taken animals from nature and used them for study.  An example of this is the chimpanzee. In this day and age, we often take such precautions as quarantines just like this one.<n><n>

So Choice A is correct.<n><n>### _C_:Input _A_ _B_.The man has to walk to the basement via stairs to get a tool.  Choose the question which shows the man walks a shorter distance to the basement. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where do people traditionally get information about the world? Choices:  A: book B: meeting C: television D: guide E: newspaper<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Solution<n><n>**The answer is 'book'**.<n><n>#### Rationales:<n><n>#### Answer:<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Lizards need the sun's heat to regulate their body temperature, this is why you'll see them still on what? Choices:  A: bushes B: dessert C: books D: heat lamps E: rocks<n><n>### Response:		<n>* The suns heat will help the lizard regulate their temperature. They will still on the rock to help heat lizard up.<n>* A: Bushes - incorrect heat source and not an appropriate item to put a lizard on.<n>* B: dessert - incorrect heat source and no where for the lizard to hide and regulate their temperature.<n>* C: Books - incorrect heat source and the books will not have direct heat on the lizard to help regulate the temp.<n>* D: Heat lamps - incorrect heat source and will not help the lizard to regulate their temperature.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		Where does a shadow usually appear on earth?<n><n>### Explanation: A shadow normally appears on a planet on which light is being received by the earth and that planet will provide an object that shields this light, which is being blocked away on the earth therefore producing a shadow on the earth.<n><n>### Input2:  A: susurfce of moon B: building,C,D,E: ground<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>### Exaption explanation:  If this light is being received and an object on this earth shielding away the light which produced a shadow then this will be the shadow on the earth.

Choices:  A: hiding B: accidentally C: expectation D: knowingly E: planned<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:<n>The two options that describe his action is knowingly and planning. His choices are expectations, hidings, accidentally, and knowingly<n>Since he ruined the surprise, he must have knowingly done that  or have planned to do that. Both of the options are knowingly and planning.<n><n>### If you had said accidentally or knowingly, the robot would have accepted your response. However, you used the other two options. The robot needs to evaluate your response. Therefore, the robot will NOT acknowledge whether you made an error or if your response was incorrect. This function is used to test your comprehension of the programming language. This is not a program or script.  The robot will only accept one of the two options. The robot will NOT acknowledge if you made an error. Here are your choices:<n>![CORRECT](http://static.instructables.com/FREE/E9A/GI1YBQK1/CORRECT.png)<n>![INCORRECT](http:static.instructables.com/FREE/7UA/Y44/YN3GXK56/INCORRECT.png "INCORRECT")<n><n>### So please use one of the two options only. Be sure to read the question carefully.<n><n>### In summary, you can only use either:<n>1. Knowingly or planning or<n>2. Accidentally or expectation<n><n>### To answer the question correctly, you need to only use one of the two choices.<n><n>### This is a language test. If you read the question, you will recognize the two choices. Do you understand those options?<n><n>### If so, you should only use knowingly or planning and accidentally or expectation.<n><n>### It should be clear now. Be sure to read your question.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>Input:<n>> George ruined the surprise. When the child turns sixteen, it is time to apply for a permit. A) A driver's permit is only given after the driver has demonstrated that he/she is qualified to drive.  B) After a  child's  sixteenth birthday, his/her parents are asked to begin teaching him/her to drive.  C) Driving instruction is a good opportunity for a parent to teach his/her child how to be considerate and safe around the  roads.  D) A driver is legally qualified to drive a car only if he/she has completed specific driving lessons.<n><n>### Rationales:C)<n><n>### Solutions

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where above your kitchen sink could you store canned food? Choices:  A: cupboard B: oven C: grocery store D: pantry E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		For this exercise we are answering the question "where above your kitchen sink could one store canned food." The choices are: A, B, D, E and C. Option A, B and D cannot store canned food since they are located in the kitchen or a home for that matter, that being said, all of our options are either part or not part of the kitchen. C is the only option that stores canned food as it is a grocery store. And since it states that it must be above any of the choices, it means it has to be above the kitchen sink which is located in the kitchen, and given this, then option to store canned food above the kitchen sink must be option E which is the store cellar.<n><n>### Input<n>How long did it take you to memorize the words to the entire song?<n><n>### Response<n>In order to answer this question we must first answer the question of how did it take you to learn the entire song, and the answer to that will be answered in steps.<n><n>First, answer the question asking when did you learn it or how to you learn it?<n><n>Well, you learned it in small parts right? Right, that means that you learned it in steps which is equivalent to the question "how?" since you are asking how you learned it and the answer to that question is how? which means in this case small parts. And what did you learn it with? For example, you have memorized a small part of the song and then after memorizing the small part you add another small part to it and then once you achieved that add on a third part to the end of it. Now that you have added on another part to the end then you add another small part from the begining in which you will add it to the end. And how do you know when you are done? Well, as you are doing this you ask yourself if you know at least 1500 words of the song right? 1500 is the size of the song to be in your head. After doing this for a moment or so and then you say that you know the song. And do you feel it? Yes, there is a chance it could be in your head, but maybe there is a small part that you don't know it all of yet or 100% which means you don't know the song completely. After you did 1500 in your head
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where is a road known as a motorway? Choices:  A: scotland B: europe C: race track D: new jersey E: england<n><n>### Response:		The name of the road is a motorway.<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: mouth B: jars and all faces C: kentucky fried chicken D: hand E: human<n><n>### Response:		 C<n><n>### The question asks, What part of the body are<n>Lips on?<n><n>Five choices are given as answers and these are a mouth, a jars, all faces, Kentucky fried chicken, and a hand<n><n>Lips are on the mouth and the mouth is on a human<n><n>The word Human and the letters k f c can be rearranged to become Human Flick<n><n>The word kentucky can be rearranged and spelled backwards to become kyekcullnt<n><n>The word kyekcullmtn and ykmcukllent are spelled backwards<n><n>The word ykmcnckkulet is spelled backward<n><n>The word yamkcnukeclet is spelled back to front<n><n>The word cnuaemkyklet is spelled backwards<n><n>The word ncuykmaklet is spelled back down<n><n>The word maucuyklenaklet is spelled backwards<n><n>A kyekcull and a cup flick are two different ways something that is spelled backwards could be spelled backward<n>The kyekcull is what the human is holding in which they are spelling backward, which is<n>Human Flick.<n><n>The cup flick is what they are using to spell backward, which is spelled below<n><n>The question asked, What part of the Body are lips on?<n>Based on the responses, we know the body is the Mouth and the choice is C.<n><n>### Direction: Fill in the blank with the correct answer.<n><n>#### 26<n>Answer: A<n><n>### The number of people who died in the 2011 Tohoku Japan earthquake and subsequent radioactive contamination was 26.<n><n>### 14 days was approximately how long the Fukushima nuclear power plant leaked radioactivity.<n><n>### The 15th letter of the Greek alphabet is called the final letter.

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:If you hit someone while driving what could happen to that person? He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The shark was migrating between continents, where did biologists find it? Choices:  A: fresh water B: gulf of mexico C: open ocean D: television program E: coral reef<n><n>### Response:		D. Biologists found the shark in a national television program<n><n>### Output:How much did it cost to print all of the materials for all of the tests? Choices: 0 A: 0 B: 12 C: 60 D: 300 E: 3000<n><n>### Response E. 3000. I could see 12 because I counted 12<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What does one chop us a grape for? How much did one slice of John's pizza cost?<n>Rational: Each slice is $6.50-$6.00 which is 50/12 which is $<<5/12=0.417>>0.417 cents.<n><n>Input: What does one chop us up a grape for?<n>Answer: Choices: <<"1"="fruit basket" or fruit">=>(a) fruit<<<n><n>### Input Questions<n><n>### First Question:<n>How was the amount of water in your glass before you added water to it?<n>Rational:<n>#### The amount of water in your original glass (before you added the water to it) is equal to 350ml-(60ml+80ml) which is 230ml.<n><n>### Second Question:<n>How many mangoes did it take to equal 20 fruit?<n>Rational: It took <<"mangoes"="fingers">>3 fingers to equal 20 fruits. Choices:  A: backpack B: closet C: drawer D: dinner E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		<n>Utensils are not used during dinner and the other five choices are incorrect. Solution C and solution D are both incorrect because they both sum up, but to 44 and not 68<n>			Solution E is false because 14 > 13 and the result should be 13<n>			Solutions F and G are both false because they both 20<n>			Soltion His true and it sums up to 20.<n><n><n>### Input<n>Instruction: Input 5 numbers. To calculate the first 2 numbers that is the sum of 5 numbers.  If the summation is 5. Use the first 2 to calcultae the third number and so on until all 5 numbers has been calculated.<n><n>### Input <n>

Also water is important for hunter gatherer communities to stay alive.<n><n>### Example:<n>A- baking?  Havenâ€™t heard of that with cavemen.<n>B- Water farming? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What is a useful activity when experiencing loneliness? Choices:  A: meet people B: meet friend C: make people laugh D: socialize E: liquor<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- You can choose a,b or c, which makes people laugh.<n>- Or choose d, which is socialization.<n>- You can also choose e, liquoring.<n><n>### The answers:<n><n>- A<n>- B<n>- C<n>- D<n>- E

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Sam didn't like the people he met while traveling.  What might he do to get away from them? Choices:  A: come home B: airplane C: learn from each other D: go out E: make art<n><n>### Response:		What letter should be put in place of the question mark in the prompt? Choices: A B C D E<n><n>**Rationales:**<n><n>A =<n>"Get away from them" (opposite of get with each other)<n>A =<n>Don't want people you meet to be your friends<n><n>B =<n>He doesn't like the plane, so leave it<n>Leaving a plane is the opposite of staying on a plane<n><n>C =<n>Learn something from each other, not leave<n>Opposite of leave<n><n>D =<n>Leave the situation, not make art<n>Leaving the environment is the opposite of making art in it<n><n>E =<n>If you meet someone, you would be spending time with them<n>He does not want to spend time with the people he just met<n><n>####<n>Answer:E<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Choose three options from the drop-down menus to create a number sentence.<n><n>Number sentences should represent the relationships for each of the numbers provided. Each number sentence should tell us a relationship between the three given values for one of the equations below.<n><n>Equations:<n><n>$5 + 23 + 43 = < 5 + 23 = 28 ><n><n>$45 + 2 * 3 = < 45 + = 240 ><n><n>$4 + 2 * 2 + 3 = < 6 + = 28 > <n><n>Use a line under each equation to separate it from the number sentence.<n><n>### Additional Information:<n><n>#### How to use each of the menu bars:<n><n>The drop-down menus under the each of the equations are labeled with an X over an X. The X over X represents the numbers of each equation you should use for your number sentence. The X and the number are a visual representation of this equation. This equation represents the number line. The X (equal to the number) represents the line on the right. The number is the number between the two line represent this equation.<n><n>#### How to create a number sentence:<n><n>1. Choose three numbers to use for your number sentence from the menus (e.g. 1, 2, and 3; or 5, 11, and 8).<n>2. Choose whether you want

I want to create a new 4 letter word by rearranging letters starting from the last to first letter.  What options are available, and what is the most efficient way to find these options? The new word cannot be same as the original one.<n><n>### Response<n>#### 2**N-1<n>The number of options is 2**N-2, where N is the number of letters<n>#### 2**(N-2)<n>```<n><n>## Example<n><n>### Instructions<n>Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>##<n>##<n>### Input:<n>Input:<n>I buy one apple for $3, 2 oranges for $1.70, 3 bananas for $3, 4 peaches for<n>$1.60,  5 plums for $2.70, 6 blueberries for $4.30 and 7 pears for $3.40. How<n>much money do I save if I buy 10 apples, bananas and 10 oranges?<n><n>### Rationales<n>For a fruit you only include the cost of the fruit for the calculation<n>```<n><n>## Demo<n><n>### Input <n>Input: I buy one apple for $$$$3, 2 or<n>anges for $1.>>1.70,<n>3 bananas for $$$$3$, 4 pl<n>ums for $$$$1.60$, 5<n>blueberries for<n>$$$4.30$$, 6 pears for $$$3.40$$. How<n>much money  do I save if I<n>buy 10 apples<n>bananas and 10<n>oranges?<n>```<n><n>## Response<n>#### 196.30<n>For the apple we put 1*$$$3 =  $<$3>3<n>For the orange we put 2*1.

How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Who sits at the center table at a receeption? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What is KFC who serves chicken? Choices:  A: fast food restaurant B: plate C: bowl D: freezer E: oven<n><n>### Response:		KFC serves chicken

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:John spent too much money buying products for his swollen testicles. Choices:  A: edge B: desire to win C: friendship D: rivalry E: skill<n><n>### Response:		<n>One should think of how valuable is the game.  There are different levels to what one needs in a game from edge to rivalry.  The different levels are<n>- The Edge<n>This level is simply when you do your best and the game will be as good as you make it.  That being said, the more time and effort you put into the game, the more it will mean to you.  It takes up time and has effects on you mind set.<n><n>- Skills<n>- Wanting to win<n>- Friendships<n>- Rivalry<n>All of these different levels will have different effects on you.  The edge will affect you more mentally, while needing to win will really make you think about your situation, desiring rivalry is going to make you look at the game from the perspective of your opponents as well as your own and friendships are what keeps you focused on your goals.<n><n>### Input/Answer:<n>Choose the answer that best explains the scenario.<n><n>Answer: The answer is:<n><n>    A. Friendship<n>   <n>Explanation:<n><n>As the question explains, people want different things out of competition. Most people want to win the games, which means they are competitive. Others may only want to develop skills or just participate in a hobby. Some players play for the fun or the friends only.<n><n>### Coding:<n><n>I first made an if statement that would have the program ask for the players initials (the first word) and their age (the second word) of the players name. I then used switch statements and a case statement. I used the switch and case statements so that no matter how many people are playing in an event, I could have multiple things for every switch statement.<n><n>### Demo:<n><n>- Here is the demo:<n>- This is what the program will ask for to start.<n>- First player has to enter their initials, then their age<n>- Then it will ask for the second players things<n>- Then third<n>- And so on<n><n>- When the program reaches a certain stage, like player 4, the program will start to check who won.  The checker will say it was the person to write the least code.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>- If we had a program that would make a baseball game without you doing any code, this is what it would be.

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. There are 12 chickens in the pan. How many of them have I'm guessing?" choices: A: 1/4 B: 1 C: 2 D: 3 E: 4<n><n>### Rationale:<n>There are 12 chicken in the pan/one-forth<n>The first 3 guesses are: 1 2 3 that's 3/12=<<3/12=1/4>>1/4.<n>So there are 5 guesses left.<n>So: 1/4+1/4+1,2=1,4<n>So there are only 2 chickens left.<n>Therefore the answer is D.<n><n>## Codability<n>- [x] Code the number that represents the answer.<n>- [x] Write the algorithm to complete the request of the above instruction.<n><n>

Choices: 1. not sad 2. sad 3. not tell him at all<n><n>### Response 2: Tell him he's coming on Saturday. I went to the gum.<n>2. I went to bed early.<n>3. I had some friends over.<n><n>### Or another options: <n><n>I went to the store.<n>I watched a movie.<n>I got up a lot.<n><n>### Question 7<n><n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where do you buy treats for kids over a counter? Choices:  A: candy store B: butcher shop C: kitchen D: auto repair shop E: post office<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Input: John decided to take a break from work. He picked the place, and the menu, on a whim. He took his coworkers to the candy store. As expected, everyone has a great time, and they've had so much fun that they stayed another two hours than they planned. In hindsight, John should have chosen the butcher shop.  He forgot to pick up his friend the meat from his butcher shop to make sandwiches at lunch. He was also running out of ideas for a weekly lunch meeting at work.<n><n>#### E<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Input: The post office is a mail center. You could do anything from sending packages, letters, and bills as well as getting the latest news.<n><n>### Answer:<n>####B<n><n>### Rations:<n>Input: A butcher shop does not sell what you are buying. Anything you can buy from the candy store or any other shop that sells candy, you can get from the butcher shop as well.<n><n>### Input-Answer:<n>Input: John took some candy from the candy store to work for the bosses; he made sure the boss had a sweet tooth.<n><n>### Output:<n>There's nothing the candy store can do when they find out the candy was stolen. They'll have to pay for it. The boss is not happy after receiving his favorite candy treat. You can either stop the ship's speed by adding a force which is proportional to the momentum. Or you can decrease the speed in a way that is proportional to how much the boat already is moving. Your task is to write two statements that demonstrate how to stop the ship. One will be written in Python, the other will be demonstrated graphically. You may use any Python code that we covered in this class. Please include a description for your statement.<n><n>#### I.python.<n>In this program you are going to use a while True loop to generate every single iteration of the program. The loop ends when you say so with a break. In each iteration you are calculating momentum using the following variables: 0 for x-axis, 1 for y-axis, 2 for z-axis, 3 for the change in movement on each axis. In each iteration you will add a force that is proportional to the momentum you calculate. When adding that force, you will use the add operation to add a vector. You will be calculating speed as well, if speed of a new iteration is greater than 1 (meaning over the speed limit) you will start slowing the ship down (adding an opposite force to the previous force) until that force is 0 and speed is less than 1.<n><n>#### II.Graphical<n><n>Input: the ship will stop by increasing speed in a way that it is proportional to how much it is moving.<n><n>#### III.Graphical<n><n>### Comments:<n>#### I.python<n>#### II.<n>#### III.<n>

Five minutes later, a second train leaves Station B bound forStation X (121 miles away).  At the same time the first train left Station A, the second train arrives at Station B.  A) How long does it take the second train to leave station B if it traveled at 125 mph?<n><n>### Solution:73 seconds (121 miles / 125 m.ph = 0.964hrs = 73seconds)<n><n>### Demotion:When the trains meet at station B in equal time (5 minutes), then train number 2 leaves in 73 seconds (1/6 of every hour which is 525 seconds).<n><n>### Answer:(525/6)*5 = 73

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. Choices:  A: ghost town B: third world country C: human body D: rug E: hospital<n><n>### Response:		 A: gin town<n>#### A<n><n>### Instructor Notes:  If the student responded with either B, C, D, or E in their response to the input, the student must revise their answer and insert it in between the parenthesis in the first sentence, for example, "Where is disease often spread, but shouldn't be." Insert the correct value here. The student must complete the sentence correctly in order to be marked correct.<n>Input:  A: gist town, B: therd world cuntary, C: rumn body, D: rug, E: hops<n><n>### Response to Input:  You are given two letters, A or B. Choose the correct answer:  A: A B: B<n><n>### Instructions:  If the student chose the wrong letter, they earn a +10 points penalty.<n><n>### Rationales: Choice A:<n>Its a ghost town and babies/toddlers are a disease and dont deserve to live in a ghost town!<n><n>Choice B:<n>Its a third world country and babies/ toddlers are still human and deserve to be treated fairly in a third world country<n><n>Choice C:<n>Its a human body and babies/to toddlers are still a part of the human body<n><n>Choice D:<n>Its a rug and babies/ children are fragile and delicate to the touch and shouldnt be used to wipe dust of a rug<n><n>Choice E:<n>Its a hospital and babies/children are human and should be helped even in a hospital<n><n>#### A<n><n>#### B<n><n>#### C<n><n>#### D<n><n>#### E<n><n>### Instance:<n>I had a really stressfull week this week. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where is a snake likely to reside? Choices:  A: tropics B: nightmare C: wyoming D: bushes E: feild<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>#### <n><n>### Inputs: Which is more expensive, a laptop with good internal hardware, or a laptop with good aesthetics?<n><n>### Response A: good internal hardware is likely to be more expensive<n><n>### Response B: good aesthetics is likely to be more cheap<n><n>## Description<n>The instruction that you have written contains one or more errors.<n><n>- [x] Explain how the errors you found can adversely [x] Explain which steps you will take to correct the incorrect [x] Explain what will happen (to your classmates) if you do not correct the errors you have found<n><n>### Examples<n>Let me fix my car.<n>```<n>- [x] Write the steps needed to fix your car.<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where would you hear a viola along side many other string and brass instruments? Choices:  A: symphony B: band C: create music D: orchestra E: string quartet<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration:The answer for the music question is a. The viola is a string instrument so it would be in an orchestra<n><n>When answering the multiple choice question the answers from left to right are orchestra, orchestra, string quartet, string quartet, orchestra, band, band, brass, brass, symphony, symphony.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Where are small grapes used? Choices:  A: picnic basket B: wine press C: juice D: fruit cocktail E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		Grapes are often used to make wine or put in fruit cocktail.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:What do all humans have on the side of their head? Choices:  A: michigan B: stable C: race track D: farm yard E: arizona<n><n>### Response:		<n>[Arizona](Arizona).<n><n>### Feedback:<n>There are many animals that would live in a _horse_'s habitat. A cow would also live in a _cow_'s habitat. If you were to guess where a cow would live you could make a correct guess by picking answer C. <n><n>### Input The owner of a pizza shop needs to hire new employees to provide better and faster service for customers. The owner was offered a 10% commission when he increases the number of employees from 15 to 25. He was also offered a 20% commission when he increase the number of employees from  25 to 35. He knows that the commission he is offered for a given increase will be the maximum amount that he can earn.  Find the maximum amount of money he will gain.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>If he increases the number of people he will receive 0+<n><n>So the maximum amount of money we can gain is $$14$$$.<n><n>### Input : What is $23 * $5?<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>$23 * $5 = 23 x 5<n>$23 * 5 = 23 * 10/2<n><n>$2360<n><n>### Rationnelles :<n><n>* First I divided 5 by 2 to get 2.5. Then I multiply with 23 to get $2360$<n><n>### Input You have $$12$$ marbles with a total value of $$20$$.  You decide to give $$3$$ marbles to your sister.  You decide you will throw away the marble with the smallest value. What is the value of the marble you throw away?<n><n>### Response The answer is $$5$$<n><n>### Raisons<n><n>The value of the marble that I will throw away is $$5$$.<n><n>I will throw away the smallest marble<n>### Input Find the value of $ 9 + $5 + $44 - $95$<n><n>### Response 45<n><n>### Rations<n><n>9+5+44-95 <n><n>**The new line is 40**<n><n>9+5-95 <n>so the equation becomes $ 9
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:James kept a clipboard where he could easily find  it.  Where might he keep it? Choices:  A: shelf B: place of work C: desk D: office supply store E: school<n><n>### Response:		James kept the clipboard in a place of work. He bought a desk, and kept items such as a keyboard and the clipboard on the desk. He kept his place of work at work. <n><n>### Input 1 and its response:<n>The answer for Question  was correct at <<Q+Answer=A>>A<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:Why shouldn't you walk barefooted after the rain? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>### Input:The doctor recommended washing hands, what was being promoted? Choices:  A: cold hands B: wet floor C: health D: become wet E: dry skin<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Hand washing is a proven way to keep healthy. But you don't actually lose weight from washing hands. And it's impossible to get wet skin dry. And you don't really change from one option to the next. <n><n>### Input<n>The student scored 89 on his Math quiz. Which of the following scores would make his percent perfect?<n>A-<n>100 B-<n>89 C-<n>80 D-<n>79 E-<n>70<n><n>### 80<n>Answer:80<n><n>## Demo:89/100*1+89/101*2+88/102*2+87/103*3+...+89/99*8+...+89/.99*89%=89/89=1 (1+0+.1(2-1)+0+...+0)*89/99=89<n><n>### Input, 4,5+6,43+61<n>### Demo, 1,6/1,3=4; 2,5/2,4=5; 3,4/3,3=6; 4,5/4,2=1; 5,6/5,6=45; 61/62=0; or any fraction that's not possible<n>#### 45<n>Answer: 45<n><n>### Input100$100+1000$2000+3001$4001= $4001<n>### Demo:7=7+10-1$=$10-1=0 $0+7*-1=$0+$7-$1$="$4001"<n>#### 4000<n>Answer: 0<n><n>## Tips<n>Do a lot of questions and get to know the format. Some people can learn from reading tips but most people learn better from doing a lot of problems.<n># Risk management<n>Ask the teacher for guidance as it is not a good idea to attempt a course (or study unit) that is too challenging.<n># Learning styles<n>People have different personalities and will find certain types
